title: AI’s Insane Energy Problem Just Got Solved… By Natural Gas

transcript.text:
Investors have been going bananas over the nuclear 
energy AI trade, but they may be missing out on

something much bigger. While everyone's waiting 
for the nuclear buildout, it's only 5 years away

now, companies are turning to other sources of 
energy. Elon Musk just built one of the largest

and fastest built data centers ever, and he used 
natural gas to power it. Many of today's largest

data centers are using natural gas and experts 
think it's only just beginning. Is natural gas

getting ready to boom on the back of the AI trade? 
We'll answer that question. And we'll also let you

in on a little known stock that's working with 
Musk and X AI on their data center energy needs.

So this chart by Goldman Sachs shows just how much 
energy is going to be needed for the massive data

center buildouts that are happening. And famed 
tech investor Andreessen Horowitz just did a

really interesting two-part series on everything 
you need to know about the US natural gas industry

that's powering AI. Now that's not hyperbole. 
That's actually happening in front of the meter

and behind the meter. So in front of the meter, 
this would actually be utility scale generation.

So the power companies we're all familiar with, 
their transmission infrastructure etc. Then you

have behind the meter, which is commercial and 
residential energy storage. So if you look at

the state of California, for example, behind the 
meter, all those solar installations they have

are said, by the California Energy Commission, 
to only have displaced around 10% of front of

the meter electricity from utilities. So that's 
still quite a small chunk even in a solar-rich

state like California because most behind the 
meter is actually solar. The largest chunk of

front-of-the-meter is actually natural gas. Here 
you can see where that's broken down. So this was

from 2023, but the numbers are still largely the 
same. These ratios you have fossil fuels, nuclear,

and, of course, renewables. And look under there. 
Fossil fuels. 43% of electricity generation in

the United States comes from natural gas. By 
far the largest source. Now, there's really

two main reasons for this. First is, and I was 
again surprised to find this out, the US is the

largest producer of natural gas in the world. And 
there's three US regions that produce more natural

gas than most countries. You can see those spelt 
out here in this very nice diagram. Natural gas

is actually one of the cheapest forms of energy. 
When it comes to generating electricity, we always

point to Lazard's levelized cost of energy, which 
takes into account things like subsidies. And you

see the two cheapest here, what they refer to as 
conventional generation. You have gas-combined

cycle and US nuclear. And gas-combined cycle 
is the cheapest form of energy. So then you

would expect that to be the most economical. Now, 
of course, there's a sensitivity there to fuel

prices, natural gas. And this great chart again 
by Lazard shows that sensitivity, and it's not

that meaningful, but it's certainly something 
that's worth considering when you look at the

price of natural gas over time. This great chart 
simply plots that out over the past 10 years.

The big spike that you see there in 2022, that's 
primarily due to the supply shock from Russia,

the second largest producer of natural gas when 
they invaded Ukraine. That was the impact on

the price of natural gas. And you can see it's 
making new highs, and we're going to talk about,

perhaps, why that is. Now, this piece that was 
commissioned by Andreessen and written by this

gentleman here who, I suppose, has given his job 
some sort of a vested interest in natural gas. So,

you need to take what he says with a grain 
of salt, but it's a very informative piece.

And it talks about how solar is not going to be 
the most effective tool to solve the AI energy

crisis as much as Musk would like it to be. Down 
the road perhaps, but right now it isn't. And

he's saying that we need to start building out 
more natural gas energy production right now or

we're going to end up doing that down the road 
anyway. This great chart, you see the yellow,

this is the daily power-generation stack and it 
shows when power becomes available. And of course,

solar power is only available when the sun shines. 
So then you need all this expensive infrastructure

to store the energy and to transmit it when the 
sun isn't shining. That increases the cost of

solar significantly. Along the bottom there, 
you see nuclear. That always stays the same,

right? And then you have red there which is 
natural gas which of course has to respond

to a certain extent to the availability of 
electricity from other intermittent sources

such as solar. And when we look at where the 
largest data centers are being powered from,

the sources of energy, it's natural gas. Here 
you can see again a great chart by Andreessen

showing data centers in various countries and the 
methods of electricity generation they're using,

the largest there, using gas. Now, going to the 
grid isn't the answer for immediate expansion for

obvious reasons, right? Everybody's complaining 
about their electricity prices going up because

all the data centers are moving into the 
neighborhood. Behind the meter is the answer. So,

that's really generating your own electricity 
that doesn't come from the grid, and it doesn't

impact anybody, except, perhaps, the environment. 
That's certainly something to consider. And lots

of new data centers being built are running off of 
behind-the-meter natural gas with plans to replace

these sources later. So behind-the-meter could be 
anything, from on-site gas turbines to fuel cells.

And this report by Goldman says that behind the 
meter systems are expected to provide a quarter

to a third of the incremental electricity demand 
from data centers that's anticipated through 2030,

the chart we looked at earlier. That's a pretty 
significant amount. When we look at Colossus,

so this is the massive data center that X AI 
built. Musk driving this. They told him it

would take 730 days. They built this data center 
in 122 days. That's simply remarkable. When we

look at where Musk's turbines come from, there's 
a company called Solaris trading under the ticker

SEI. And they have a past that isn't so bright. 
So they were valued at around $1.65 billion and

they suffered five straight quarters of falling 
revenues in their legacy oil field services.

That's before they pivoted and acquired a company 
called Mobile Energy Rentals, and they rebranded

this as Solaris Power Solutions, shifting their 
focus to gas-powered turbine leasing for data

centers. All right. When you start to break down 
Solaris, you see that 96% of last year's revenue

for that energy generation unit came from leasing 
revenue from xAI. So, I mean, do you really want

to be sitting across the table from Musk having 
negotiations? No. You're not in a very good

position. He's going to be able to strongarm you 
all over the place, and he certainly will. And

Bloomberg correctly titles this article, Solaris 
ties its future to xAI's success in the AI boom.

refers to this 7-year agreement that they have, 
though Musk could connect to the grid sooner than

that. Presumably, he will. And what happens to 
this company that's hedged their entire success

right now in xAI? xAI is leasing, and when you 
do that, you really don't have to worry a lot

about risk. So, we don't know what the terms 
of those leases look like, but when you look on

the back end, Solaris is sourcing these units 
from either purchasing them, subleasing them,

or even refurbishments. So this really isn't an 
ideal solution. It seems to be what Musk could

cobble together quickest to get that data 
center up and running. So it doesn't bode

well necessarily for Solaris. And if Musk plugs 
into the grid and gets his solar farms online,

then it really makes these turbines obsolete. 
Maybe they move to the next Colossus data center

that's being built and they're just a temporary 
solution whilst Musk works as fast as he can to

deploy data centers. For anybody that finds that 
story compelling enough to invest in, Hindenburg

linked Morpheus targeted Solaris in their first 
short report. Here's how that works. If you're an

investor in any company, you should be stoked when 
a firm issues a short report because they've gone

out there and found every single red flag, every 
single reason not to invest in a company. They've

done that for you. And then you can vet that and 
decide if you still want to make an investment.

Don't be a Dgen and just pull an ostrich and put 
your head in the sand. You read the report. You

see what takeaways are and you say, "Yeah, I think 
we'll stay invested." So, we see natural gas being

used by data centers. And when you look at the 
Stargate AI data center being built by OpenAI,

it's going to be the world's largest AI 
supercluster once it's fully built. And Sam Altman

made the remark here. He said, "We're burning gas 
to run this data center again." And he says, "But

the hope is to rely on many other power sources." 
Of course, we know Altman's connection with Oklo

Nuclear coming down the road. We did a piece on 
that, looking at how it may not be the panacea to

the AI energy woes, right? It's going to take 
a long time to build out, and some of these

concepts are not proven at all. The SMR modular 
concepts, there's a lot of them out there, and for

investors, you really need to watch that piece. If 
you think that nuclear energy is the way forward

and be aware of the risks that are inherent to 
that thesis. So why not build out these small

gas turbines and just use these extensively across 
all data centers? The fuel is cheap, right? These

modular systems must be cheaper. Well, they're not 
really. So they actually have a much higher cost

than that of the large combined-cycle natural gas 
turbines. But here's an interesting comment. Their

modular nature makes them cost-competitive because 
what you can do is this. You have to have a 100%

uptime, right? So if you have a 500 megawatt 
power plant and that goes down, you have to have

another 500 megawatt power plant as a backup. 
Well, if you have five 100 megawatt turbines,

these smaller installations, you only, perhaps, 
need to have two as backups because you're only

ever going to have one go out at a time, or 
perhaps two. So they're saying here that that

actually makes them a lot more cost-competitive. 
And they go on to talk about how these solid

oxide fuel cells, such as those produced by Bloom 
Energy, have higher upfront and maintenance costs

but are far more fuel efficient, as we talked 
about, 10 to 30%. Of course, that advantage

erodes as the price of natural gas falls. But 
the other advantage there is when you look at

some of these lawsuits being leveled at Musk, 
that they're talking about environmental impact,

and it's a lot easier, they say, for these 
fuel cell installations to get permits than

it is for dirty gas turbines. Right? So investment 
angles, aside from Solaris that we talked about,

which wouldn't be appealing from where we're 
sitting, for reasons that we gave, investing

in spot natural gas commodity investment. You see 
this a lot. It's really speculative because it's

quite cyclical, right? It's really a speculative 
thesis than it is saying, well, gas is going to

go up perpetually because of the demand. No, it's 
not how it works, right? And for those of you that

are looking for ETFs, you may come across this 
United States Natural Gas Fund under the ticker

UNG. This is not a good investment. Probe around 
a little bit there. Says nothing to do with giving

you exposure to the price of natural gas. It's 
about speculating on intra-day movements. You

go look at the 10-year return is something like 
a loss of 99%. You can read the definitions as

to how this vehicle works. Really, investing in 
spot natural gas is the least desirable way to

get exposure to this thesis. You have natural 
gas producers and pipeline infrastructure. So,

you then end up investing in a lot more than just 
the growth of data centers. This LNG thesis also

comes into play. And you can read these pieces by 
Andreessen. They're rather verbose, but they sort

of tie that in. The argument being that, well, LNG 
actually needs to pull back so that data centers

can use all this natural gas instead of selling 
it. Then you have the manufacturers of turbines.

So when it comes to the larger-scale units, 
the type of turbines being used by these large

combined-gas cycle plants, we did a piece that 
looked at Caterpillar in that context. Commons.

There's other firms out there building them. 
They talk about a seven-to-eight-year backlog.

But they're also quite wary, in terms of ramping 
that up, because they know, and this comment here,

from that earlier article, bulls may view this as 
an opportunity, but the restraint shown by larger

manufacturers serves as a reminder to investors 
that heated markets do not always last. So,

they're very wary of any sort of buildout. And 
then when you look at any company, be aware of

the actual exposure you're getting. Again, going 
back to that piece we did on Caterpillar, looking

at how you get very little exposure to that thesis 
by investing the stock. So, just some thoughts

here. Seems like front-of-meter expansion, so 
these combined gas cycle plants, they're going

to take a long time to ramp up because of the 
turbine backlog. Back-of-the-meter solutions can

certainly provide some temporary capabilities 
while solar gets built out. That appears to be

what Musk is doing, right? And then when nuclear 
energy comes online, later on down the road,

right, it's very expensive. And when you look at 
how much it's moving the needle, it really is not

very much. But eventually, we're going to start to 
gravitate again towards what's economical. Going

back to that chart that Lazard has, which shows 
the most efficient forms of energy generation,

always beware of booms that are temporary, right? 
As long-term investors, we want a thesis that

extends beyond just half a decade. Now, Bloom 
Energy, a few premium subscribers have asked us

about that. So, we're going to be covering their 
fuel cell deployments in a coming piece. We've

certainly covered that firm for a very long 
time. Haven't looked at them for a while. So,

we'll definitely take a look at that next. And 
if you're interested in reading more about what

the state of nuclear energy is all about, we did 
this recent piece, quite popular, which looks at

just that. Give that a watch next. Thanks so much 
for taking the time to watch this video today.
